<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1
to the financial statements of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of
these policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Mississippi Power&#146;s
results of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could
produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements.
See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical
Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete
discussion of Mississippi Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric
Utility Regulation, Contingent Obligations, Unbilled Revenues, and Plant Daniel Operating Lease.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Overview</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s financial condition remained stable at June&nbsp;30, 2008. Net cash provided from
operating activities totaled $1.0&nbsp;million for the first six months of 2008, compared to $120.8
million net cash provided from operating activities for the corresponding period in 2007. The
$119.8&nbsp;million decrease in net cash provided from operating activities in the first six months of
2008 was primarily due to the receipt of grant proceeds of $74.3&nbsp;million in June&nbsp;2007 and an
increase in receivables in 2008 in the amount of $38.8&nbsp;million, of which $22.1&nbsp;million was
associated with affiliate receivables. This was due primarily from increased Power Pool sales and
gas settlements. Also, an $18.1&nbsp;million change in prepaid income taxes was primarily due to a
refund received in the first quarter 2007. The $20.8&nbsp;million increase in net cash used for
investing activities in the first six months of 2008 is primarily due to increases in cost of
removal, net of salvage and increases in construction payables due to new construction projects.
Net cash provided from financing activities totaled $57.1&nbsp;million for the first six months of 2008,
compared to $70.9&nbsp;million used in financing for the corresponding period in 2007. The $128.0
million increase in net cash provided from financing activities was primarily due to the $80
million long-term bank loan made to Mississippi Power on March&nbsp;5, 2008 and the $36&nbsp;million
redemption of the long-term debt to an affiliated trust in the first six months of 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Significant balance sheet changes for the first six months of 2008 include an increase in fossil
fuel stock, at an average cost of $30.5&nbsp;million, primarily due to increases in coal and gas of
$10.4&nbsp;million and $17.5&nbsp;million, respectively. Assets from risk management activities increased by
$37.1&nbsp;million, primarily due to increases in forward gas prices. Securities due within one year
increased by $40.0&nbsp;million due to the current portion of the senior note maturing in 2009. Also,
other regulatory liabilities increased by $43.8&nbsp;million primarily relating to increases in the fuel
hedges as a result of increased gas prices.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Mississippi Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, lease
obligations, purchase commitments, derivative obligations, preferred stock dividends, and trust
funding requirements. Approximately $41.2&nbsp;million will be required through June&nbsp;30, 2009 for
maturities of long-term debt.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->107<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from
sources similar to those utilized in the past. Mississippi Power has primarily utilized funds from
operating cash flows, short-term debt, external security offerings, and equity contributions from
Southern Company. However, the amount, type, and timing of any future financings, if needed, will
depend upon regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions, and other factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Mississippi
Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s current liabilities frequently exceed current assets because of the continued
use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet scheduled maturities of long-term debt as well
as cash needs which can fluctuate significantly due to the seasonality of the business. To meet
short-term cash needs and contingencies, Mississippi Power had at June&nbsp;30, 2008 approximately $4.1
million of cash and cash equivalents and $181&nbsp;million of unused committed credit arrangements with
banks. Of these facilities, $141&nbsp;million expire in 2008 and $40&nbsp;million expire in 2009.
Approximately $39&nbsp;million of these credit arrangements contain provisions allowing two-year term
loans executable at expiration and $15&nbsp;million contain provisions allowing one-year term loans
executable at expiration. Mississippi Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed,
prior to expiration. See Note 6 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Bank
Credit Arrangements&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information. These credit
arrangements provide liquidity support to Mississippi Power&#146;s commercial paper program and have
$40.1&nbsp;million dedicated to funding purchase obligations related to variable rate pollution control
bonds. Mississippi Power may also meet short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary
organized to issue and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and for
the benefit of Mississippi Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At June&nbsp;30, 2008,
Mississippi Power had $20.6&nbsp;million of commercial paper outstanding. Management believes that the
need for working capital can be adequately met by utilizing commercial paper programs and lines of
credit without maintaining large cash balances.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Off-Balance Sheet
Financing Arrangements&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 7 to the financial statements of
Mississippi Power under &#147;Operating Leases&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information related to
Mississippi Power&#146;s lease of a combined cycle generating facility at Plant Daniel.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in
payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain
contracts that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit
rating change to below BBB- or Baa3. These contracts are primarily for electricity sales, coal
purchases, and purchases of emissions allowances. At June&nbsp;30, 2008, the maximum potential
collateral requirements at a rating below BBB- or Baa3 were approximately $50&nbsp;million. Generally,
collateral may be provided by a Southern Company guaranty, letter of credit, or cash.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power, along with all members of the Power Pool, is party to certain energy-related
derivative agreements that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a
credit rating change to below investment grade for Alabama Power and/or Georgia Power. These
agreements are primarily for natural gas and power price risk management activities. At June&nbsp;30,
2008, Mississippi Power&#146;s total exposure to these types of agreements was approximately $68
million.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->108<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed
materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2007 reporting period. In addition, Mississippi Power is
not aware of any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near
term.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Due to cost-based rate regulation, Mississippi Power has limited exposure to market volatility in
interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks
relative to movements in electricity prices, Mississippi Power enters into physical fixed-price
contracts for the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market.
Mississippi Power has also implemented retail fuel-hedging programs at the instruction of the
Mississippi PSC and wholesale fuel-hedging programs under agreements with wholesale customers.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The changes in fair value of energy-related derivative contracts and valuations at June&nbsp;30, 2008
were as follows:

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gains and losses on energy-related derivative contracts related to Mississippi Power&#146;s fuel hedging
program are initially recorded as regulatory liabilities and assets, respectively, and then are
included in fuel expense as they are recovered through the energy cost management clause. Certain
other gains and losses on energy-related derivatives, designated as hedges, are initially deferred
in other comprehensive income before being recognized in income in the same period as the hedged
transaction. Gains and losses on energy-related derivative contracts that are not designated as
hedges are recognized in the statements of income as incurred.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Unrealized pre-tax gains recognized in income for the three months and six months ended June&nbsp;30,
2008 for energy-related derivative contracts that are not hedges were $1.5&nbsp;million and $1.8
million, respectively, and were not material for the three months and six months ended June&nbsp;30,
2007.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->109<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As part of the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;157 to increase consistency and comparability in fair value
measurements and related disclosures, the table above now uses the three-tier fair value hierarchy,
as discussed in Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein, as opposed to the previously
used descriptions &#147;actively quoted,&#148; &#147;external sources,&#148; and &#147;models and other methods.&#148; The
three-tier fair value hierarchy focuses on the fair value of the contract itself, whereas the
previous descriptions focused on the source of the inputs. Because Mississippi Power uses
over-the-counter contracts that are not exchange traded but are fair valued using prices which are
actively quoted, the valuations of those contracts now appear in Level 2; previously they were
shown as &#147;actively quoted.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note
(F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In March&nbsp;2008, Mississippi Power entered into an $80&nbsp;million long-term bank loan that bears
interest based on one-month LIBOR with a three-year maturity. Proceeds were used to repay a
portion of Mississippi Power&#146;s short-term indebtedness and for other corporate purposes, including
Mississippi Power&#146;s continuous construction activities.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also in 2008, Mississippi Power converted its entire $42.6&nbsp;million of obligations related to
auction rate tax-exempt securities from an auction rate mode to a fixed rate mode.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements, contractual
obligations, and storm restoration costs, Mississippi Power plans to continue, when economically
feasible, a program to retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost
capital if market conditions permit.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->110<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED BALANCE SHEETS (UNAUDITED)
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="76%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<DIV align="left">
<A name="138"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="Center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">SECOND QUARTER 2008 vs. SECOND QUARTER 2007<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2008 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2007

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power and its wholly-owned subsidiaries construct, acquire, own, and manage generation
assets and sell electricity at market-based prices in the southeastern wholesale market. Southern
Power continues to execute its regional strategy through a combination of acquiring and
constructing new power plants and by entering into PPAs with investor owned utilities, independent
power producers, municipalities, and electric cooperatives.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">To evaluate operating results and to ensure Southern Power&#146;s ability to meet its contractual
commitments to customers, Southern Power focuses on several key performance indicators. These
indicators include peak season equivalent forced outage rate (EFOR)&nbsp;and net income. EFOR defines
the hours during peak demand times when Southern Power&#146;s generating units are not available due to
forced outages (the lower the better). For additional information on these indicators, see
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW &#150; &#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Southern Power
in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Net Income</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3">Second Quarter 2008 vs. Second Quarter 2007</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3">Year-to-Date 2008 vs. Year-to-Date 2007</TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="7" valign="top" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

    <TD align="center" valign="top"><I><FONT style="white-space: nowrap"><FONT style="font-size:8pt">(change in millions)</FONT></FONT></I>
</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top"><I><FONT style="white-space: nowrap"><FONT style="font-size:8pt">(% change)</FONT></FONT></I>
</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top"><I><FONT style="white-space: nowrap"><FONT style="font-size:8pt">(change in millions)</FONT></FONT></I>
</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top"><I><FONT style="white-space: nowrap"><FONT style="font-size:8pt">(% change)</FONT></FONT></I></TD>
</TR>

    <TD align="center" valign="top">$(4.5)
</TD>

</TD>

</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top">(10.4)</TD>

<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="7" valign="top" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s net income for the second quarter 2008 was $35.4&nbsp;million compared to $39.9&nbsp;million
for the corresponding period of 2007. This decrease was primarily due to timing of plant
maintenance activities, increased depreciation associated with the implementation of a new
depreciation study, and increased depreciation associated with Plant Oleander Unit 5 and Plant
Franklin Unit 3 being placed into commercial operation in December&nbsp;2007 and June&nbsp;2008,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s net income for year-to-date 2008 was $64.4&nbsp;million compared to $71.9&nbsp;million for
the corresponding period of 2007. This decrease was primarily due to mark to market losses on
forward sales of uncontracted generating capacity, transmission service and tariff penalties
incurred during the first quarter 2008, timing of plant maintenance activities, increased
depreciation associated with the implementation of a new depreciation study, and increased
depreciation associated with Plant Oleander Unit 5 and Plant Franklin Unit 3 being placed into
commercial operation in December&nbsp;2007 and June&nbsp;2008, respectively. These unfavorable impacts were
partially offset by a gain on the sale of an undeveloped tract of land and the receipt of a fee for
participating in an asset auction during the first quarter 2008. Southern Power was not the
successful bidder in the asset auction.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->116<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Wholesale Revenues </I></B><B>&#150; </B><B><I>Non-Affiliates</I></B>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Wholesale energy sales to non-affiliates will vary depending on the energy demand of those
customers and their generation capacity, as well as the market cost of available energy compared to
the cost of Southern Power.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Wholesale revenues from non-affiliates for the second quarter 2008 were $170.9&nbsp;million compared to
$98.1&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2007. Wholesale revenues from non-affiliates for
year-to-date 2008 were $251.4&nbsp;million compared to $179.2&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in
2007. These increases were primarily due to increases in short-term market energy revenues,
increased energy revenues due to higher natural gas prices, and revenues from the operation of
Plant Oleander Unit 5. Mark to market losses on forward sales of uncontracted generating capacity
arising from an increase in forward market prices partially offset this increase.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Power Sales Agreements&#148;
of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Wholesale Revenues </I></B><B>&#150; </B><B><I>Affiliates</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt">N/M &#150; Not Meaningful
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Wholesale energy sales to affiliated companies within the Southern Company system will vary
depending on demand and the availability and cost of generating resources at each company. Sales
to affiliate companies that are not covered by PPAs are made in accordance with the IIC, as
approved by the FERC.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Wholesale revenues from affiliates for the second quarter 2008 were $143.9&nbsp;million compared to
$143.9&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2007. Two offsetting factors impacted wholesale
revenues from affiliates during the quarter. An increase of $30.3&nbsp;million resulting from higher
natural gas prices was offset by a $30.9&nbsp;million decrease primarily due to decreased demand as a
result of milder weather in the second quarter 2008 than in the corresponding period in 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Wholesale revenues from affiliates for year-to-date 2008 were $277.4&nbsp;million compared to $253.4
million for the corresponding period in 2007. This increase was primarily due to an increase of
$47.6&nbsp;million resulting from higher natural gas prices. Partially offsetting this increase was a
$25.3&nbsp;million decrease primarily due to decreased demand as a result of milder weather in the
second quarter 2008 than in the corresponding period in 2007.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->117<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

    <TD align="right" valign="top" style="border-top: 3px double #000000; border-top: 3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap valign="top">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD align="right" valign="top">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD valign="top">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the second quarter 2008, total fuel and purchased power expenses were $175.6&nbsp;million compared to
$106.8&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2007. These increases were primarily due to higher
fuel and purchased power costs of $83.4&nbsp;million due to an increase in the average cost of fuel and
purchased power. Mark to market gains of $11.7&nbsp;million on forward natural gas derivatives and a
$2.9&nbsp;million decrease due to decreased generation offset a portion of the total increase.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2008, total fuel and purchased power expenses were $278.9&nbsp;million compared to
$176.5&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2007. These increases were primarily due to
increased generation and purchases of $13.6&nbsp;million in order to meet the higher energy sales as
well as higher fuel and purchased power costs of $114.4&nbsp;million due to an increase in the average
cost of fuel and purchased power. Mark to market gains of $25.6&nbsp;million on forward natural gas
derivatives offset a portion of these increases.
</DIV>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the second quarter 2008, other operations and maintenance expenses were $35.7&nbsp;million compared
to $29.8&nbsp;million for the same period in 2007. This increase was primarily due to timing of plant
maintenance activities of $4.8&nbsp;million and an increase in general and administrative expenses of
$2.4&nbsp;million primarily related to the implementation of the FERC separation order. This increase
was partially offset by a decrease in transmission expenses of $1.3&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2008, other operations and maintenance expenses were $70.7&nbsp;million compared to
$55.9&nbsp;million for the same period in 2007. This increase was primarily due to timing of plant
maintenance activities of $8.6&nbsp;million, general and administrative expenses of $3.8&nbsp;million
primarily related to the implementation of the FERC separation order, and transmission service and
tariff penalties of $2.4&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->118<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the second quarter 2008, depreciation and amortization was $20.9&nbsp;million compared to $18.3
million for the corresponding period in 2007. For year-to-date 2008, depreciation and amortization
was $40.9&nbsp;million compared to $36.7&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2007. These increases
were primarily due to the completion of Plant Oleander Unit 5 in December&nbsp;2007 and Plant Franklin
Unit 3 in June&nbsp;2008 and higher depreciation rates implemented in January&nbsp;2008.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt">N/M &#151; Not Meaningful
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the second quarter 2008, the change in other income (expense), net was not material.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For year-to-date 2008, other income (expense), net was $12.6&nbsp;million as compared to $1.1&nbsp;million
for the corresponding period in 2007. This change is primarily due to a $6.0&nbsp;million gain on the
sale of an undeveloped tract of land and a $6.4&nbsp;million fee received for participating in an asset
auction. Southern Power was not the successful bidder in the asset auction.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Income Taxes</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3">Second Quarter 2008 vs. Second Quarter 2007</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3">Year-to-Date 2008 vs. Year-to-Date 2007</TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the second quarter 2008, income taxes were $24.5&nbsp;million compared to $25.7&nbsp;million for the
corresponding period in 2007. For year-to-date 2008, income taxes were $41.4&nbsp;million compared to
$47.2&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2007. These decreases were primarily due to
decreases in earnings before taxes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Southern Power&#146;s future
earnings potential. A number of factors affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of
Southern Power&#146;s competitive wholesale energy business. These factors include the ability to
achieve sales growth while containing costs. Another major factor is federal regulatory policy,
which may impact Southern Power&#146;s level of participation in this market. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors, including regulatory matters (such as those related to affiliate contracts), sales,
creditworthiness of customers, total generating capacity available in the Southeast, and the
successful remarketing of capacity as current contracts expire. For additional information
relating to these issues, see RISK
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->119<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">FACTORS in Item&nbsp;1A and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of
Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Construction Projects</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Plant Franklin Unit 3</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power completed construction of Plant Franklin Unit 3 in June&nbsp;2008. Costs incurred
through June&nbsp;30, 2008 were $308.6&nbsp;million. The unit is a natural gas-fueled combined cycle located
in Smiths, Alabama with a nameplate capacity of 648 MW. The unit will be used to provide annual
capacity for a PPA with Constellation Energy Group, Inc. from 2009 through 2015.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Power Sales Agreements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power signed extensions of existing contracts with 10 members of the Georgia Electric
Membership Corporation (EMC). Eight contracts were extended beginning in 2010 through 2031 and two
contracts were extended beginning in 2013 through 2034. The EMCs are currently projected to
purchase 500 MWs in 2008 under these agreements. Their purchases are projected to grow to more
than 1400 MWs during the extension.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;  FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148;
of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for information on the
development by federal and state environmental regulatory agencies of additional control strategies
for emission of air pollution from industrial sources, including electric generating facilities.
Compliance with possible additional federal or state legislation or regulations related to global
climate change, air quality, or other environmental and health concerns could also affect earnings.
While Southern Power&#146;s PPAs generally contain provisions that permit charging the counterparty
with some of the new costs incurred as a result of changes in environmental laws and regulations,
the full impact of any such regulatory or legislative changes cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Carbon Dioxide Litigation</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On February&nbsp;26, 2008, the Native Village of Kivalina and the City of Kivalina filed a suit in the
U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against several electric utilities
(including Southern Company), several oil companies, and a coal company. The plaintiffs are the
governing bodies of an Inupiat village in Alaska. The plaintiffs contend that the village is being
destroyed by erosion allegedly caused by global warming that the plaintiffs attribute to emissions
of greenhouse gases by the defendants. The plaintiffs assert claims for public and private
nuisance and contend that the defendants have acted in concert and are therefore jointly and
severally liable for the plaintiffs&#146; damages. The suit seeks damages for lost property values and
for the cost of relocating the village, which cost is alleged to be $95&nbsp;million to $400&nbsp;million.
On June&nbsp;30, 2008, all defendants filed motions to dismiss this case. Southern Company believes
that these claims are without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory or regulatory
basis for the claims. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->120<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power is involved in various other matters being litigated and regulatory matters that
could affect future earnings. In addition, Southern Power is subject to certain claims and legal
actions arising in the ordinary course of business. Southern Power&#146;s business activities are
subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public health and the environment.
Litigation over environmental issues and claims of various types, including property damage,
personal injury, common law nuisance, and citizen enforcement of environmental requirements such as
opacity and air and water quality standards, has increased generally throughout the United States.
In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials
have become more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such potential litigation against Southern Power
and its subsidiaries cannot be predicted at this time; however, for current proceedings not
specifically reported herein or in Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from any
such proceedings would have a material adverse effect on Southern Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various other
contingencies, regulatory matters, and other matters being litigated which may affect future
earnings potential.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power prepares its consolidated financial statements in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described
in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Southern Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could produce estimates
that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting
Policies and Estimates&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete discussion of
Southern Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Revenue Recognition, Normal
Sale and Non-Derivative Transactions, Cash Flow Hedge Transactions, Mark-to-Market Transactions,
Percentage of Completion, Asset Impairments, Acquisition Accounting, and Contingent Obligations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Depreciation</I></B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Depreciation of the original cost of assets is computed under the straight-line method and applies
a composite depreciation rate based on the assets&#146; estimated useful lives determined by management.
The primary assets in property, plant, and equipment are power plants, all of which have an
estimated composite life ranging from 29 to 37&nbsp;years. These lives reflect a weighted average of the
significant components (retirement units) that make up the plants. Depreciation studies are
conducted periodically to update the component depreciable lives and salvage values. See Note (J) to the Condensed Financial Statements herein
for a discussion of changes in depreciation assumptions made by Southern Power effective January 1, 2008. Southern Power is currently undertaking an additional review of the
estimated useful lives of its assets and further changes may be warranted which could increase depreciation.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">When property subject to composite depreciation is retired or otherwise disposed of in the normal
course of business, its cost is charged to accumulated depreciation. For other property
dispositions, the applicable cost and accumulated depreciation is removed from the accounts and a gain or loss is
recognized.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->121<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Business Combinations</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In December&nbsp;2007, the FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;141 (revised 2007), &#147;Business Combinations&#148;
(SFAS No.&nbsp;141R). SFAS No.&nbsp;141R, when adopted, will significantly change the accounting for
business combinations, specifically the accounting for contingent consideration, contingencies,
acquisition costs, and restructuring costs. Southern Power plans to adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;141R on January
1, 2009. It is likely that the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;141R will have a significant impact on the
accounting for any business combinations completed by Southern Power after January&nbsp;1, 2009.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In December&nbsp;2007, the FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;160, &#147;Non-controlling Interests in
Consolidated Financial Statements&#148; (SFAS No.&nbsp;160). SFAS No.&nbsp;160 amends Accounting Research Bulletin
No.&nbsp;51, &#147;Consolidated Financial Statements&#148; to establish accounting and reporting standards for the
non-controlling (minority)&nbsp;interest in a subsidiary and for the deconsolidation of a subsidiary.
It clarifies that a non-controlling interest in a subsidiary should be reported as equity in the
consolidated financial statements and establishes a single method of accounting for changes in a
parent&#146;s ownership interest in a subsidiary that do not result in deconsolidation. Southern Power
plans to adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;160 on January&nbsp;1, 2009 and is currently assessing its impact, if any.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Overview</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s financial condition remained stable at June&nbsp;30, 2008. Net cash provided from
operating activities totaled $46.0&nbsp;million for the first six months of 2008, compared to $96.9
million for the corresponding period in 2007. The $50.9&nbsp;million decrease in cash provided from
operating activities in the first six months of 2008 is primarily due to costs incurred on the
construction of the combined cycle unit for the Orlando Utilities Commission and timing of tax
payments. Net cash used for investing activities totaled $57.5&nbsp;million for the first six months of
2008, compared to $94.4&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2007 due to completion of Plant
Oleander Unit 5 in December&nbsp;2007 and Plant Franklin Unit 3 in June&nbsp;2008. Net cash provided from
financing activities totaled $11.5&nbsp;million for the first six months of 2008, compared to net cash
used for financing activities of $29.8&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2007 due to changes
in levels of short-term debt.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Significant balance sheet changes for the first six months of 2008 include increases in assets and
liabilities for Southern Power&#146;s risk management activities due to increases in the forward prices
for power and natural gas. Other asset changes include the completion of the sale of land that was
held for sale at December&nbsp;31, 2007, the timing of tax payments, and increases in customer accounts
receivable due to seasonality. Other liability changes include a reduction in other current
liabilities due to payment of IGCC termination costs of $2.6&nbsp;million, a reduction of deferred
capacity revenues due to seasonality, and increases in accounts payable due to increased prices in
energy and fuel.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Southern Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program,
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->122<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">maturing debt, interest, leases, derivative obligations, purchase commitments, and long-term
service agreements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In June&nbsp;2008, Southern Power entered into an agreement to purchase power in the years 2011- 2015.
The purchase commitment will be approximately $20.5&nbsp;million for years 2011-2012 and a total of
$45.0&nbsp;million for the years after 2012.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power may use operating cash flows, external funds, or equity contributions from Southern
Company to finance any new projects, acquisitions, and ongoing capital requirements. Southern
Power expects to generate external funds from the issuance of unsecured senior debt and commercial
paper or utilization of credit arrangements from banks. However, the amount, type, and timing of
any financings, if needed, will depend upon regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions, and
other factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150;
&#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s current liabilities frequently exceed current assets due to the use of short-term
indebtedness as a funding source, as well as cash needs which can fluctuate significantly due to
the seasonality of the business. To meet liquidity and capital resource requirements, Southern
Power had at June&nbsp;30, 2008 approximately $400&nbsp;million in committed credit arrangements with banks
that expire in 2012. Borrowings of $95&nbsp;million under these arrangements were outstanding as of
June&nbsp;30, 2008. Proceeds from these credit arrangements may be used for working capital and general
corporate purposes as well as liquidity support for Southern Power&#146;s commercial paper program.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s commercial paper program is used to finance acquisition and construction costs
related to electric generating facilities and for general corporate purposes. At June&nbsp;30, 2008,
there was $11.4&nbsp;million of commercial paper outstanding.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Management believes that the need for working capital can be adequately met by utilizing commercial
paper programs and lines of credit without maintaining large cash balances.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in payment
schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain contracts
that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit rating change
to BBB and Baa2 or to BBB- or Baa3 or below. These contracts are primarily for physical
electricity purchases and sales. At June&nbsp;30, 2008, the maximum potential collateral requirements
at a BBB and Baa2 rating were approximately $9&nbsp;million and at a BBB- or Baa3 rating were
approximately $317&nbsp;million. At June&nbsp;30, 2008, the maximum potential collateral requirements at a
rating below BBB- or Baa3 were approximately $603&nbsp;million. Generally, collateral may be provided
by a Southern Company guaranty, letter of credit, or cash.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In addition, Southern Power is party to a PPA that could require collateral, but not accelerated
payment, in the event of a downgrade to Southern Power&#146;s credit rating to below BBB- or Baa3. The
amount of collateral required would depend upon actual losses, if any, resulting from a credit downgrade,
limited to Southern Power&#146;s remaining obligations under the contract.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->123<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power, along with all members of the Power Pool, is party to certain agreements that could
require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a credit rating change to below
investment grade for Alabama Power and/or Georgia Power. These agreements are primarily for
natural gas and power price risk management activities. At June&nbsp;30, 2008, Southern Power&#146;s total
exposure to these types of agreements was approximately $68&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed
materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2007 reporting period. In addition, Southern Power is
not aware of any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near
term.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power is exposed to market risks, including changes in interest rates, certain
energy-related commodity prices, and, occasionally, currency exchange rates. To manage the
volatility attributable to these exposures, Southern Power nets the exposures to take advantage of
natural offsets and enters into various derivative transactions for the remaining exposures
pursuant to Southern Power&#146;s policies in areas such as counterparty exposure and hedging practices.
Southern Power&#146;s policy is that derivatives are to be used primarily for hedging purposes. Derivative positions are monitored using techniques
that include market valuation and sensitivity analysis.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Because energy from Southern Power&#146;s facilities is primarily sold under long-term PPAs with tolling
agreements and provisions shifting substantially all of the responsibility for fuel cost to the
counterparties, Southern Power&#146;s exposure to market volatility in commodity fuel prices and prices
of electricity is generally limited. However, during 2008, Southern Power is exposed to market
volatility in energy-related commodity prices as a result of sales of uncontracted generating
capacity.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The change in fair value of energy-related derivative contracts and valuations at June&nbsp;30, 2008
were as follows:
</DIV>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">(29.7</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">(29.7</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="9" align="left" style="border-top: 3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">
<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96"></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(a)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Current period changes also include the changes in fair value of new contracts entered into
during the period, if any.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gains and losses on energy-related derivatives used by Southern Power to hedge anticipated
purchases and sales are initially deferred in other comprehensive income before being recognized in
income in the same period as the hedged transaction. Gains and losses on energy-related derivative
contracts that are not designated or fail to qualify as hedges are recognized in the statements of
income as incurred.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->124<!-- /Folio -->

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Unrealized pre-tax gains/(losses) recognized in income for the three months and six months ended

$(8.5) million, respectively, and will continue to be marked to market until the settlement date.
Unrealized amounts were not material for the three months and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2007.

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As part of the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;157 to increase consistency and comparability in fair value
measurements and related disclosures, the table above now uses the three-tier fair value hierarchy,
as discussed in Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein, as opposed to the previously
used descriptions &#147;actively quoted,&#148; &#147;external sources,&#148; and &#147;models and other methods.&#148; The
three-tier fair value hierarchy focuses on the fair value of the contract itself, whereas the
previous descriptions focused on the source of the inputs. Because Southern Power uses
over-the-counter contracts that are not exchange traded but are fair valued using prices which are
actively quoted, the valuations of those contracts now appear in Level 2; previously they were
shown as &#147;actively quoted.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements of Southern Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)
to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power did not issue or redeem any long-term securities during the six months ended June
30, 2008.

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">(A)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>INTRODUCTION</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The condensed quarterly financial statements of each registrant included herein have been
prepared by such registrant, without audit, pursuant to the rules and regulations of the
SEC. The Condensed Balance Sheets as of December&nbsp;31, 2007 have been derived from the
audited financial statements of each registrant. In the opinion of each registrant&#146;s
management, the information regarding such registrant furnished herein reflects all
adjustments, which, except as otherwise disclosed, are of a normal recurring nature,
necessary to present fairly the results of operations for the periods ended June&nbsp;30, 2008
and 2007. Certain information and footnote disclosures normally included in annual
financial statements prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in
the United States have been condensed or omitted pursuant to such rules and regulations,
although each registrant believes that the disclosures regarding such registrant are
adequate to make the information presented not misleading. Disclosures which would
substantially duplicate the disclosures in the Form 10-K and details which have not changed
significantly in amount or composition since the filing of the Form 10-K are generally
omitted from this Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q. Therefore, these Condensed Financial
Statements should be read in conjunction with the financial statements and the notes thereto
included in the Form 10-K. Due to the seasonal variations in the demand for energy,
operating results for the periods presented do not necessarily indicate operating results
for the entire year.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Certain prior period amounts have been reclassified to conform to current period
presentation. Where applicable, each registrant&#146;s statements of income for the three months
and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2007 were modified to report &#147;Interest expense to affiliate
trusts&#148; together with &#147;Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized.&#148; In addition, where
applicable, the financing activities section of each registrant&#146;s statement of cash flows
for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2007 was modified to report &#147;Long-term debt to affiliate
trust&#148; together with &#147;Long-term debt.&#148; Also, where applicable, each registrant&#146;s balance
sheet at December&nbsp;31, 2007 was modified within the current liabilities section to present a
separate line item for &#147;Other regulatory liabilities&#148; previously included in &#147;Other.&#148; Due
to materiality in the current period, the balance sheets of Southern Company, Alabama Power,
Georgia Power, and Mississippi Power were modified to present a separate line item for
&#147;Assets from risk management activities&#148; previously included in &#147;Other&#148; in the prior period.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Southern Company&#146;s current liability section of the balance sheet at December&nbsp;31, 2007 was
modified to reflect the amount of &#147;Unrecognized tax benefits&#148; as a separate line item
previously included within &#147;Accrued taxes&#151;Income taxes.&#148; Also, Southern Company&#146;s
statement of cash flows for the prior period was modified within the operating activities
section to present separate line items for &#147;Derivative fair value adjustments&#148; and &#147;Deferred
revenues&#148; previously included in &#147;Other, net.&#148;</TD>
</TR>

    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

settlements&#148; previously included in &#147;Other, net.&#148; Additionally, the line item &#147;Material and
supplies&#148; was combined into &#147;Other current assets.&#148;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">

    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>included in &#147;Other income and expense, net.&#148; In conjunction with such modification, Gulf
Power modified its statement of cash flows within the operating activities section to
present a separate line item for &#147;Allowance for equity funds used during construction&#148;
previously included in &#147;Other, net.&#148; In addition, the operating activities section now
includes a separate line item to present &#147;Hedge settlements&#148; previously included in &#147;Other,
net&#148; in the prior period.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Due to the relative insignificance of the amount reported at June&nbsp;30, 2008, the balance
sheet at December&nbsp;31, 2007 of Mississippi Power was modified to combine assets in &#147;Prepaid
income taxes&#148; into &#147;Other.&#148;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Southern Power modified its statement of cash flows for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2007
to present a separate line within the investing section for &#147;Payments pursuant to long-term
service agreements&#148; previously included in &#147;Property additions.&#148; In order to conform to the
current period presentation, Southern Power also modified its balance sheet for the prior
period to present separately the amount of &#147;Prepaid income taxes.&#148; The remaining amount of
assets in &#147;Prepaid expenses&#148; was collapsed into &#147;Other.&#148;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>These reclassifications had no effect on total assets, net income, cash flows, or earnings
per share.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In the first quarter 2008, Gulf Power sold a turbine rotor assembly to Southern Power for
$9.4&nbsp;million. In the second quarter 2008, Southern Power sold a turbine rotor assembly to
Alabama Power for $8.2&nbsp;million. These affiliate transactions were made in accordance with
FERC and state PSC rules and guidelines and were eliminated in consolidation for Southern
Company.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">(B)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>CONTINGENCIES AND REGULATORY MATTERS</TD>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of the registrants in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
information relating to various lawsuits, other contingencies, and regulatory matters.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&nbsp;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><B>&nbsp;</B></TD>
    <TD><B>General Litigation Matters</B></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Each registrant is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary
course of business. In addition, each registrant&#146;s business activities are subject to
extensive governmental regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation
over environmental issues and claims of various types, including property damage, personal
injury, common law nuisance, and citizen enforcement of environmental requirements such as
opacity and air and water quality standards, has increased generally throughout the United
States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to
hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such pending or
potential litigation against the registrants and any of their subsidiaries cannot be
predicted at this time; however, for current proceedings not specifically reported herein or
in Note 3 to the financial statements of each registrant in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K,
management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from such current
proceedings would have a material adverse effect on such registrant&#146;s financial statements.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&nbsp;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><B>&nbsp;</B></TD>
    <TD><B>Mirant Matters</B></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Mirant was an energy company with businesses that included independent power projects and
energy trading and risk management companies in the United States and selected other
countries. It was a wholly-owned subsidiary of Southern Company until its initial public
offering in October&nbsp;2000. In April&nbsp;2001, Southern Company completed a spin-off to its
shareholders of its remaining ownership, and Mirant became an independent corporate entity.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD><I>Mirant Bankruptcy</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In July&nbsp;2003, Mirant and certain of its affiliates filed voluntary petitions for relief
under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the Bankruptcy Code in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Northern
District of Texas. The Bankruptcy Court entered an order confirming Mirant&#146;s plan of
reorganization in December&nbsp;2005, and Mirant announced that this plan became effective in
January&nbsp;2006. As part of the plan, Mirant transferred substantially all of its assets and
its restructured debt to a new corporation that adopted the name Mirant Corporation
(Reorganized Mirant).</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Southern Company has certain contingent liabilities associated with guarantees of
contractual commitments made by Mirant&#146;s subsidiaries discussed under &#147;Guarantees&#148; in Note 7
to the financial statements of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and with various
lawsuits related to Mirant discussed below. Also, Southern Company has joint and several liability with Mirant
regarding the joint consolidated federal income tax returns through 2001, as discussed in
Note 5 to the financial statements of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In
December&nbsp;2004, as a result of concluding an IRS audit for the tax years 2000 and 2001,
Southern Company paid approximately $39&nbsp;million in additional tax and interest related to
Mirant tax items and filed a claim in Mirant&#146;s bankruptcy case for that amount. Through
December&nbsp;2007, Southern Company received from the IRS approximately $36&nbsp;million in refunds
related to Mirant. Southern Company believes it has a right to recoup the $39&nbsp;million tax
payment owed by Mirant from such tax refunds. As a result, Southern Company intends to
retain the tax refunds and reduce its claim against Mirant for the payment of Mirant taxes
by the amount of such refunds. MC Asset Recovery, a special purpose subsidiary of
Reorganized Mirant, has objected to and sought to equitably subordinate the Southern Company
tax claim in its fraudulent transfer litigation against Southern Company. Southern Company
has reserved the approximately $3&nbsp;million amount remaining with respect to its Mirant tax
claim.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Under the terms of the separation agreements entered into in connection with the spin-off,
Mirant agreed to indemnify Southern Company for costs associated with these guarantees,
lawsuits, and additional IRS assessments. However, as a result of Mirant&#146;s bankruptcy,
Southern Company sought reimbursement as an unsecured creditor in Mirant&#146;s Chapter&nbsp;11
proceeding. As part of a complaint filed against Southern Company in June&nbsp;2005 and amended
thereafter, Mirant and The Official Committee of Unsecured Creditors of Mirant Corporation
(Unsecured Creditors&#146; Committee) objected to and sought equitable subordination of Southern
Company&#146;s claims, and Mirant moved to reject the separation agreements entered into in
connection with the spin-off. MC Asset Recovery has been substituted as plaintiff in the
complaint. If Southern Company&#146;s claims for indemnification with respect to these, or any
additional future payments, are allowed, then Mirant&#146;s indemnity obligations to Southern
Company would constitute unsecured claims against Mirant entitled to stock in Reorganized
Mirant. The final outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD><I>MC Asset Recovery Litigation</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In June&nbsp;2005, Mirant, as a debtor in possession, and the Unsecured Creditors&#146; Committee
filed a complaint against Southern Company in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Northern
District of Texas, which was amended in July&nbsp;2005, February&nbsp;2006, May&nbsp;2006, and March&nbsp;2007.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In December&nbsp;2005, the Bankruptcy Court entered an order authorizing the transfer of this
proceeding, along with certain other actions, to MC Asset Recovery. Under that order,
Reorganized Mirant is obligated to fund up to $20&nbsp;million in professional fees in connection
with the lawsuits, as well as certain additional amounts. Any net recoveries from these
lawsuits will be distributed to, and shared equally by, certain unsecured creditors and the
original equity holders. In January&nbsp;2006, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District
of Texas substituted MC Asset Recovery as plaintiff.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
